description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: February 25, 2020: With Bulletin N. 90, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended a meeting with EU Health Commissioner, Stella Kyriakides, and the Ministers of Health of those countries bordering with Italy: Austria, France, Slovenia and Switzerland. The Ministers of Health of Germany and Croatia also took part in the meeting. The aim of the meeting was to share and discuss information about the epidemiological situations of COVID-19 in the States. Issues about travelling and movement of goods between countries were also discussed.

description: As of 25 May, 2020, pupils in their final year of primary education in Slovenia returned to their schools, which means that nearly half of the primary and secondary school population is back in the classroom, the rest continuing learning at home. Out of 87,000 children enrolled in kindergartens in the 2019/2020 school year, 56% returned to their kindergartens a week ago. However, 38,000 children are still being looked after by their parents or grandparents.

description:
As of 25 May, 2020, pupils in their final year of primary education in Slovenia returned to their schools, which means that nearly half of the primary and secondary school population is back in the classroom, the rest continuing learning at home. Out of 87,000 children enrolled in kindergartens in the 2019/2020 school year, 56% returned to their kindergartens a week ago. However, 38,000 children are still being looked after by their parents or grandparents.
 UPDATE: The Government of the Republic of Slovenia issued an update at the press conference on 25.5.2020 regarding the policy, Closure and Regulation of Schools. 

The Director of the National Education Institute, Vinko Logaj stresses that it would be useful if pupils and students were to return to school before the end of this school year, as only a traditional classroom setting can suffice to fulfil all our education objectives.

institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions

description: On 8 March, 2021, lessons in all grades of all primary schools in the country will continue just as they have this week, under model B. Next week the remainder of secondary school pupils will return under model C. Model C provides autonomy for school principals to determine the number of pupils or the classes that will have lessons in school and then remotely. Teachers will conduct lessons in classes, and remotely for pupils who stay at home.

description: The government of Slovenia enforces a Covid-19 vaccine policy and publishes a National Strategy for vaccination against Covid on 1, March, 2021. The Strategy lays out 9 groups for vaccine administration. Three vaccines against COVID-19 are currently registered in Slovenia (Moderna, Pfizer/BioNTech, AstraZeneca), which should be used in the current situation. Considering the very limited amount of vaccines against COVID-19 in the current situation it is not possible to choose between vaccines.

Slovenia enforces a Covid-19 vaccine policy for Pfizer. On March 17, 2021, it announces that the vaccination strategy for the mRNA-based vaccine Pfizer, has to be carried out for:
group 1: 
- people aged 75 and over (Pfizer also for immobile people),
- elderly nursing-home residents who have not yet been vaccinated,
- healthcare professionals aged 65 and over who have not yet been vaccinated,
- for medical students aged 16 to 18 (Pfizer vaccine) undergoing clinical practice in healthcare facilities
group 2:
people aged 70 and over, and particularly vulnerable chronic patients, regardless of age, 
group 3: 
people aged 65 and over

description: Slovenia announced on June, 3rd, 2021 that for Covid vaccine certificates those who have recovered from COVID-19, have been vaccinated against COVID-19 or have tested negative will be issued with a uniform, universal and free-of-charge COVID certificate or digital COVID certificate and will be thus able to live relatively freely. On the zVEM web portal, citizens can access all their health data in one place, i.e. medical reports, tests and prescriptions, and reports that will be the basis for the issuing of the single COVID certificate. The smsPASS digital identity can be obtained at vaccination centres, administrative units, offices of the Financial Administration of the Republic of Slovenia (FURS), social work centres or the mailroom of the Ministry of Justice.

description: Slovenia introduced a campaign for vaccintation for Covid-19, "Vaccination Days". Between 19 and 23 December, 2021, vaccination centres in Slovenia will be open from 8 am to 8 pm, and in every statistical region a vaccination centre or vaccination point will also be open during the night (from 8 pm to 8 am). Mobile units will be organised in all municipalities. None of the vaccination points or mobile units will require a prior appointment for vaccination. Appointments will be required only for children aged 5–11. Everywhere it will be possible to choose your vaccine.

description:
On March 11, 2020, the governement of Slovenia introduces border control checks for non-Slovenian nationals and persons without permanent or temporary residence in Slovenia. This includes checking for negative COVID-19 result certificates in Slovenian, English or Italian language, not older than three days. Persons without such certificate will still be allowed to enter the Republic of Slovenia if their body temperature is below 37.5 °C and they show no clear signs of upper respiratory tract infection (cough, sneezing, shortness of breath).
Six health checkpoints will be established in the border area at road links with Italy, namely: Rateče, Robič, Vrtojba, Fernetiči, Škofije and Krvavi potok.
This order does not apply to citizens of the Republic of Slovenia, persons with permanent or temporary residence in the Republic of Slovenia and freight traffic
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On March 18, 2020, the government of Slovenia introduces border control checks on the border with Italy. Four checkpoints will be established in the border area at road connections with the Italian Republic: Vrtojba, Fernetiči, Škofije, and Krvavi potok. The checkpoints Vrtojba, Fernetiči, and Škofije will be open at all times and the checkpoint Krvavi potok from 5:00 to 23:00.
For foreign citizen, entry into the Republic of Slovenia is permitted if they present proof in the Slovenian, English or Italian language of a molecular laboratory test for the presence of SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) showing negative results for SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) no older than three days. Even if the foreign citizen does not present such a proof, they will still be granted entry into the Republic of Slovenia if their body temperature is below 37.5°C and there are no clear indications of an upper respiratory tract infection (cough, sneezing, shortness of breath).
This policy does not apply on citizens of the Republic of Slovenia and persons with a permanent or temporary residence in the Republic of Slovenia
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Slovenia is enforcing an external border restriction starting from May 18, 2020. Regarding entry into Slovenia there were no restrictions for Slovenian citizens entering Slovenia. The same applies to other citizens of the European Union who have permanent or temporary residence in Slovenia. EU citizens who show clear signs of infection or disease will be refused to enter Slovenia.

The same provisions applying to the family members of EU and Slovenian citizens will also apply to the citizens of associate members of the Schengen Area, i.e. Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Iceland.
Third-country nationals are still required to provide proof of the urgent need to travel to the EU at the external Schengen border. For such persons, the state of health, the need to travel (emergency family conditions, residence in Slovenia, carriers and others on the basis of economic reasons) and the reasons for entry in accordance with the Schengen Borders Code will be determined before entering the Schengen Area.

description:
Slovenia is enforcing an external border restriction starting from May 18, 2020. Regarding entry into Slovenia there were no restrictions for Slovenian citizens entering Slovenia. The same applies to other citizens of the European Union who have permanent or temporary residence in Slovenia. EU citizens who show clear signs of infection or disease will be refused to enter Slovenia.

The same provisions applying to the family members of EU and Slovenian citizens will also apply to the citizens of associate members of the Schengen Area, i.e. Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Iceland.
Third-country nationals are still required to provide proof of the urgent need to travel to the EU at the external Schengen border. For such persons, the state of health, the need to travel (emergency family conditions, residence in Slovenia, carriers and others on the basis of economic reasons) and the reasons for entry in accordance with the Schengen Borders Code will be determined before entering the Schengen Area.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: On July 8, 2020 the government of Slovenia enforced an external border restrition and adopted the decision that the service of quarantine decisions at the Gruškovje, Metlika, and Jelšane border crossings with Croatia, the Pince border crossing with Hungary, and at Jože Pučnik Airport should henceforth be carried out only between 6 am and 10 pm. Round the clock, 24/7 service of decisions continues at the Obrežje border crossing. At other border crossing points with Austria and Italy, quarantine decisions will be issued on the basis of data collected for the Ministry of Health as the issuer of such decisions
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
On September 30, 2020, the government of Slovenia enforced an external border restriction. 
Slovenia has enacted a general ban on travel from the United States. U.S. citizens with residency in an EU country may enter Slovenia.  For other U.S. citizens who first spend two weeks in a third country, Slovenia may grant entry, depending on the country of origin. In addition, immediate family members (but not fiancés) of Slovenian citizens coming from the United States are permitted with a transit letter from the Slovenian embassy in Washington, DC. 
The policy ended on October 2, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 26 October 2020 the government of Slovenia is enforcing an external border restriction. The Ordinance re-introduces the possibility of examining the health status of people crossing the border as per the instructions of the epidemiological service of the National Institute of Public Health at border crossing points at the external border and inspection posts within national borders of Slovenia. The policy is targeted towards all travelers entering Slovenia.

description: Border checkpoints divided into 2 types based on who is permitted to cross border and when. On March 6, the Republic of Slovenia decided to introduce new measures at its borders to contain the spread of the COVID-19 infections. The recent amendment has been effective since Monday, March 8, 2021.The border checkpoints are divided into two types, type A checkpoints and type B checkpoints, based on who is permitted to cross the border and when.At type A checkpoints, all passengers are allowed to cross the border at all times. At type B checkpoints, only people qualifying as exemptions under Article 10 are allowed to pass.Also, citizens of Slovenia, citizens of the neighbour countries Austria, Italy, and Hungary, as well as the citizens of the other Member States of the EU or Schengen Area, are allowed to cross the type B border checkpoints provided that they are residents in a municipality bordering the neighbour country or if they are residents of an administrative unit bordering Slovenia.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
target_region: European Union (without the UK),Schengen Area (without the UK)

description: Changes to the Ordinance of determining the conditions for entry in the Republic of Slovenia for the purpose of containment and control of the infectious disease COVID-19 are in force as of today. Crossing the national border outside the checkpoints is no longer possible, except for owners of land on both sides of the border engaged in forestry, agricultural and farming work.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
"Travel to red-listed countries or administrative units of countries is prohibited, except for exceptions. There are two general exceptions from this ban (persons who have recovered from COVID-19 or have been vaccinated) and all special exceptions. Schoolchildren and persons transporting them cannot claim an exception if the school is closed or if schooling is not provided.

Upon exiting the country, these persons must submit the same proof as required by this Ordinance upon entering the country."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: The government of Slovenia made changes to Slovenia's entry requirements. As of Saturday, 5 June, a negative rapid antigen test result is again accepted for entry into Slovenia, provided that less than 48 hours have passed since the swab was taken. Both PCR and rapid tests are deemed sufficient if performed in an EU Member State, a Schengen Area country, Australia, Israel, Canada, New Zealand, Russia, Serbia, the UK or the US, at check points on flight connections of international air transport, and in Turkey. One further condition applies to rapid tests: only tests that are on the common list of COVID-19 rapid antigen tests recognised by the EU Member States are valid.  There are no changes for persons who have recovered from COVID-19 or have been vaccinated; such persons may enter Slovenia without being required to quarantine.  A person arriving from an area not on the red or dark red list may enter Slovenia without being ordered to quarantine at home if upon entry they provide proof of having resided in an area that is not on the red or dark red list for at least five consecutive days prior to entry. The change here is that if the period is shorter than five days, the person is only required to provide proof for the period from the time of departure from Slovenia to their return to Slovenia. If they are not able to provide relevant proof, they are considered to have come from an area on the red or dark red list.  Otherwise,  quarantine is required.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Everyone entering Slovenia from a country on the Dark Red List or the Red List will be required to quarantine for 10 days. Quarantine can be ended after 5 days, with a negative PCR test. Quarantine can be avoided if travellers meet one of the following: they are able to provide a negative PCR test result or a negative Rapid Antigen Test that is not more than 48 hours old and that has been administered in Australia, Canada, the EU, Israel, New Zealand, Russia, the Schengen Area, Serbia, the UK or the US; or    they have proof of a COVID-19 vaccination as follows:    A second dose of Pfizer/BioNTech at least 7 days before arrival;  A second dose of Moderna vaccine at least 14 days before arrival;  A first dose of Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine at least 21 days before arrival;  A second dose of the Sputnik V vaccine at least 21 days before arrival;  The Johnson & Johnson Janssen vaccine at least 21 days before arrival;  The Serum Institute of India/AstraZeneca at least 21 days before arrival;  A second dose of the Sinovac Biotech at least 14 days before arrival;  A second dose of the Sinopharm at least 14 days before arrival;  One dose of any of the above vaccines within eight months of recovering; or  they have recovered from COVID-19 and hold immunity. Proof of immunity can be demonstrated by a written medical statement from a health
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

Quarantine can be avoided if travellers meet one of the following: they are able to provide a negative PCR test result or a negative Rapid Antigen Test that is not more than 48 hours old and that has been administered in Australia, Canada, the EU, Israel, New Zealand, Russia, the Schengen Area, Serbia, the UK or the US; or    they have proof of a COVID-19 vaccination as follows:    A second dose of Pfizer/BioNTech at least 7 days before arrival;  A second dose of Moderna vaccine at least 14 days before arrival;  A first dose of Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine at least 21 days before arrival;  A second dose of the Sputnik V vaccine at least 21 days before arrival;  The Johnson & Johnson Janssen vaccine at least 21 days before arrival;  The Serum Institute of India/AstraZeneca at least 21 days before arrival;  A second dose of the Sinovac Biotech at least 14 days before arrival;  A second dose of the Sinopharm at least 14 days before arrival;  One dose of any of the above vaccines within eight months of recovering; or  they have recovered from COVID-19 and hold immunity. Proof of immunity can be demonstrated by a written medical statement from a health
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: 3G: Must be either (i) vaccinated (ii) have a valid COVID-19 negative test within a certain time frame or (iii) recovered from COVID-19

description: Slovenia has divided countries according to colours, people not satisfying the following requirements are subject to quarantine:  Red list - a certificate of recovery, a certificate of vaccination or a certificate confirming that they have both recovered and been vaccinated;   Orange list - a European digital COVID certificate or a digital COVID certificate of a third country, a negative PCR or rapid antigen test HAG, a certificate of recovery, a certificate of vaccination or a certificate confirming that they have both recovered and been vaccinated.   Green list - proof of having resided in an area on the green list for at least five consecutive days prior to entry.   A person who fails to provide adequate proof must quarantine at home for ten days.   Persons who are not residents of Slovenia are ordered to quarantine at the address where they will actually stay. Any quarantine-related costs will be covered by the quarantined persons themselves. Foreign citizens who are not residents of Slovenia and cannot provide an address where they would stay in quarantine are not allowed entry into the country if appropriate quarantine accommodation capacities cannot be ensured.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Slovenia has divided countries according to colours, people not satisfying the following requirements are subject to quarantine:  Red list - a certificate of recovery, a certificate of vaccination or a certificate confirming that they have both recovered and been vaccinated;   Orange list - a European digital COVID certificate or a digital COVID certificate of a third country, a negative PCR or rapid antigen test HAG, a certificate of recovery, a certificate of vaccination or a certificate confirming that they have both recovered and been vaccinated.   Green list - proof of having resided in an area on the green list for at least five consecutive days prior to entry.   A person who fails to provide adequate proof must quarantine at home for ten days.   Persons who are not residents of Slovenia are ordered to quarantine at the address where they will actually stay. Any quarantine-related costs will be covered by the quarantined persons themselves. Foreign citizens who are not residents of Slovenia and cannot provide an address where they would stay in quarantine are not allowed entry into the country if appropriate quarantine accommodation capacities cannot be ensured.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: There are no changes when entering Slovenia from the so-called green countries. However, there are some changes for persons entering Slovenia from the countries on the orange list. Anyone holding either a European digital certificate or a digital COVID certificate from a third country will be able to enter the country without being ordered to quarantine. A person who fails to provide adequate proof will be quarantined at home for ten days. A person coming from an area on the red list can enter Slovenia without being referred to home quarantine if they present a certificate of recovery from COVID-19, a certificate of vaccination or a certificate of vaccination for recovered persons. A person coming from an area on the dark red list can enter Slovenia without being ordered into home quarantine if they present a certificate of recovery, a certificate of vaccination or a certificate of vaccination for recovered persons.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

Non-essential travel to Slovenia (personal/tourist) - permitted only if fully vaccinated or recently recovered from Covid-19.

description: While there is no explicit mention of scope of contact tracing carried out by the government, it does seem like it has been comprehensive. description: From Saturday, October 17, 2020, the NIJZ epidemiological service will therefore still establish contact with each person with a confirmed infection by phone , provide them with information about the course of isolation and issue a code for activation in the #StayZdrav application . In the case of an infection in a child, the epidemiological service contacts the child's parents or guardians. A person with a confirmed infection will also receive instructions to notify all persons with whom they have been in contact , and to provide them with the Instructions for persons who have been exposed to infection with the new coronavirus (available at the following link ).

description: On October 19, 2020, the government of Slovenia introduced a health monitoring measure. The #OstaniZdrav mobile application informs the user if the person has been in contact with an infected person. The #OstaniZdrav application helps contain and manage the spread of novel coronavirus infection and reduces the burden on the healthcare system, thus enabling the state to control the virus using less coercive measures. The use of the application is voluntary.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Who a person has come into contact with over time
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On 15 March, 2020, the Government of the Republic of Slovenia issued the Ordinance on the allocation of doctors without licences to be published in the Official Gazette of the Republic of Slovenia. The Ordinance enters into force on 15 March 2020 at 19.00.
Specialisation ceases for all specialist trainees, including all trainees’ obligations arising from their specialisations. Specialist trainees may be called upon to work by their employers or, by medical institutions where they are undergoing their rotation.
All obligations of interns arising from their internship are suspended for the duration of measures under this Ordinance, and they are called upon to work according to need.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The Government of Slovenia adopted the proposal for an act on the intervention measures to mitigate the consequences of the communicable disease SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) for citizens and the economy, known as the #PKP1 #antiCorona legislative package. 

One of the measures adopted by the Government to contain and control the new coronavirus epidemic was the Ordinance on mandatory disinfection of multi-dwelling buildings; the temporary prohibition of the offering and sale of goods and services to consumers; and the temporary prohibition of the operation of air services in the Republic of Slovenia.

This Ordinance will enter into force on 30 March 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of April 11, 2020, the Government of the Republic of Kazakhstan announced that for any other person entering the country, a seven-day quarantine is introduced, on the last day of which a person is required to be tested for SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) infection at one of the checkpoints (COVID-19 screening clinics). If the test is negative, the quarantine ends. If the test is positive, the person concerned is treated in accordance with professional guidelines for the treatment of persons infected with SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19).

description: As of October 28, 2020, the Government of the Republic of Slovenia announced that epidemiologists are no longer monitoring all those who have been in close contact with a person who has tested positive. Nevertheless, people who have had such contact should remain – at least in the case of a confirmed coronavirus infection within their household – in self-isolation, as it is very likely that other family members will also contract the disease.

description: As of November 26, 2020, the Government of the Republic of Slovenia announced that healthcare providers and social institutes need to carry out regular tests of persons working in their institutions. Tests are mandatory if the provider detects an infection, and must be carried out at least once a week within each organisational unit of the provider in which the infection was identified. The order states that tests are carried out from the moment of the infection, and at least 14 days following the last known infection in the organisational unit.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of December 3, 2020, the Government of the Republic of Slovenia announced the use of antigen tests for the entire population, which should be available before Christmas. The testing protocol will be introduced gradually. Rapid antigen tests will first be used in nursing homes and healthcare facilities. The next group is likely to be the majority of educators. It will be followed by other important infrastructure groups, police, military and private sector employees.

description: On Februare 12, 2021, the government of Slovenia announces that testing is available for both foreign nationals and Slovenians.  No appointment is required for the rapid antigen tests (RAT), and they are available throughout the country, including Ljubljana airport. For foreign nationals, cost for RAT is 25-30 euro. Results for both tests will be provided to you electronically within 24 hours.

description: On February 12, 2021, the government of Slovenia announces that for the PCR test, available at the Ljubljana Clinical Center, an appointment is required, but is usually available within a day. description: On March 4, 2021, the government of Slovenia announced that a mandatory testing of regular cross-border commuters will be introduced. They will have to get tested once a week from Saturday, 15 March. When crossing the border, these passengers or citizens from either side will have to produce a negative COVID-19 test.These are daily or weekly commuting cross-border workers or individuals crossing the border occasionally to provide personal assistance or care, and individuals crossing the border for education and training purposes.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: On March 28, 2021, the government of Slovenia announced that regular weekly testing will be required for staff in shops selling mainly groceries, personal care and cleaning items, garden shops, plant nurseries, florists', produce markets, newsagents and technical goods shops.

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of May 13, 2021, the Government of the Republic of Slovenia stated that the offering and sale of goods and services within the group of exceptions that demand a test is permitted only if the employees are tested once a week for the presence of SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) using the HAG (rapid test) or PCR method. Goods and services can therefore be offered and sold only by employees who have a negative test result obtained in the Republic of Slovenia.

description: On March 28, 2020, the government of Slovenia issued an Ordinance on the mandatory disinfection of equipment in common areas in or by multi-dwelling buildings at least twice per day.  The frequency of disinfection depends on the number of people living in the multi-dwelling building. In addition, a warning notice must be placed in a prominent place in front of the entrance to the lift: "The use of the lift poses a risk of transmission of COVID-19 infection, so the lift should only be used by one person at a time. After pressing the lift buttons, do not touch your eyes, nose or mouth and wash your hands.”
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Slovenia, 5.11.2020, the government of the republic of Slovenia in the press conference in regards to the current COVID-19.

The government announces that, it will extend the measures and restrictions in schools, educational institutions will remain closed. The school will start distance learning all primary, secondary and music schools will start distance-learning classes next week. At the discretion of kindergartens and mayors, kindergartens will continue to be open only for emergency childcare for parents who are unable to make other daycare arrangements.


In shopping centers it is also mandatory to provide separate entrances and exits for customers, hand disinfection dispensers at entry and exit points of premises, and regular airing or adequate ventilation of premises where services are provided.
In Addition, some services will resume such as medical pedicure, specialized children’s shops, shops selling primarily technical goods, specialized shops selling motor vehicles and motorcycles, shops selling primarily furniture, photo services, photocopying, watchmaker’s and goldsmith’s.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
In Slovenia, for the time being, the
public transport system is fully adapted in order to reduce thepotential
risk of spreading infections between passengers.
It is mandatory for passengers,
inter alia
, to wear a protective mask or other means of protecting the noseand mouth area throughout the whole duration of the transport. However, special care must be taken tonot touch one’s mask while wearing it, as this could lead
to contamination of one’s hands and the risk of spreading the infection to other passengers and objects inthe vehicle. Passengers are to enter the bus through the second or back door with a valid ticket, and whenentering the bus they must already be wearing a mask and must disinfect their hands, while alwaysmaintaining a distance of at least 1.5 meters between other passengers.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Government adopted a new ordinance under which the restriction on movement in the Coastal-Karst region will be reinstated as of Saturday, 27 February 2021. Since the epidemiological situation is fairly comparable among the municipalities in the Coastal-Karst region, and since there is only one region that has re-entered the red phase, the Government decided that movement would be restricted throughout the entire region, and not just in the individual municipalities within that region.    Therefore, public assembly is prohibited in the Coastal-Karst region, and entry into and departure from the Coastal-Karst region is also prohibited. Schools in the region remain open.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

See Government of the Republic of Slovenia news website, archived:

description: Authorities in Slovenia have eased domestic COVID-19-related restrictions effective April 12; from this date, the nightly curfew is lifted and many nonessential businesses and services are permitted to resume operation subject to strict hygiene and social distancing measures.    Movement between statistical regions is prohibited with certain exceptions for which adequate proof must be submitted.  Movement between regions is also allowed for individuals who: submit a negative test result; submit a certificate of vaccination for COVID-19; submit positive PCR or HAG test result older than 21 days; persons with a doctor’s certificate proving that they have recovered from COVID-19.

description: As of April 16, 2021, the Government of the Republic of Slovenia stated that movement between statistical regions is allowed in the following cases (travel to and from work and the performance of work duties; the performance of business, agricultural and forestry activities; the elimination of immediate threats to health, life and property; the provision of care and assistance to persons in need of support, care of family members, or parental care or contact with one’s children; access to pharmacies, health and sanitary services, and health resort treatment; access to foreign diplomatic missions and consular posts; access to emergency services; access to the performance of tasks related to the operation of judicial, administrative and law enforcement authorities; access to services for persons with special needs; the performance of maintenance work or seasonal chores on private property for members of the same household; the travel of persons who have entered the Republic of Slovenia in order to transit to a neighbouring country or to their residence in the Republic of Slovenia; access to shops or services in another municipality that are closer to the person's residence than the same shops and services in the municipality of their residence or if there are no such shops or services in their municipality; urgent maintenance of a grave, in which case the person must demonstrate their eligibility with proof of burial plot lease or other appropriate proof.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Ordinance sets out the business hours for grocery stores, which will begin no later than at 8:00 and end no earlier than at 20:00 every day. From 8:00 to 10:00, all vulnerable groups, which include disabled persons, retired persons and pregnant women, will be given priority in making purchases as well as entering a shop. All shops will be closed on Sundays and work-free days except petrol stations and pharmacies, which may operate.

description: While work from home and staying indoors is encouraged, within their municipality people were allowed to go to shops and access services that are provided despite the sweeping lockdown. description:
The Government of the Republic of Slovenia to ease coronavirus lockdown from Monday.  

Most shops, including those selling furniture, cars, bicycles and construction material as well as car service centers will be opened from April 20. Also, Hairdressers, beauty parlors and pet grooming centers will open on May 4.

Schools, kindergartens, universities, libraries and cultural institutions remain closed, while public transport continues to be suspended.

description:
On February 27, 2020, the government of Slovenia announced the establishment of a new Bureau in the Ministry of the Interior.
In order to respond effectively in the event of the spread of the coronavirus in Slovenia, the Minister of the Interior established an internal coordination working group, while the State Secretary participates in the government's working group for managing the situation related to the emergence of the coronavirus, which, among other things, also coordinates the joint response of departments and proposes measures to the government regarding the control of the virus.

description:
The government of Slovenia enforces a 7-day quarantine for people entering Slovenia. On the last day of quarantine it is mandatory to undergo testing for SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) infection. The policy enters into force on April 12, 2020.
People falling under some exceptions do not have to comply to this policy, e.g. commuting cross-border workers, citizens of the Republic of Slovenia and foreigners who travel through Slovenia to another country in the same day; persons with diplomatic passports; persons who provide emergency services and other exceptions.

description: The government of Slovenia enforces a 14-day quarantine on all people entering Slovenia who refuse to to allow swabbing for testing on the 7th day. The is also a 14-day quarantine if the swab cannot be taken for other reasons. The policy enters into force on 12 April, 2020. People falling under some exceptions do not have to comply to this policy, e.g. commuting cross-border workers, citizens of the Republic of Slovenia and foreigners who travel through Slovenia to another country in the same day; persons with diplomatic passports; persons who provide emergency services and other exceptions.

description: On September 28, 2020 the government of Slovenia enforces a new policy for quarantine meaures. All countries coming from the red or the orange list have to undergo a 10-day self-quarantine, unless they they submit a negative SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) test, which must not be older than 48 hours and was performed in another EU Member State or Schengen Area country or Slovenia by an organisation that has been recognised as appropriate. A total of 12 exceptions have been defined where no quarantine or negative test is required upon entry even if a person enters Slovenia from a country on the orange or the red list. The policy ends on Spetember, 30 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
From September 30, 2020 the Principality of Andorra, the Principality of Monaco, the Republic of San Marino and the Vatican City State are treated in the same way as the Member States of the Schengen area and can thus be cathegorized as green states that do not need to undergo a  quarantine.
States listed in the red and orange list have to undergo a 10-day self-quarantine, unless they they submit a negative SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) test, which must not be older than 48 hours and was performed in another EU Member State or Schengen Area country or Slovenia by an organisation that has been recognised as appropriate. Various exceptions have been defined where no quarantine or negative test is required upon entry even if a person enters Slovenia from a country on the orange or the red list. The policy ends on October 2, 2020.

description: On November 16, 2020, the government of Slovenia enforces a 10 day quarantine for people arriving in Slovenia from a country on the red list. However, people entering Slovenia will not be required to quarantine if they provide a negative test result for the presence of SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19), which must not be older than 48 hours, or if they fall under one of the exceptions. As opposed to the proevious policy implemented, persons who own real estate in a neighbouring country do not fall under the exceptions. The policy ends on Dec. 19, 2020.

description: On January 28, 2021, Slovenia enforces a quarantine on people entering Slovenia and applicates different set of rules for different categories. People that have spent at least 14 days in a country from the green list before entering Slovenia do not have to quarantine or show a negative test result. Travellers arriving in Slovenia from a EU Member State or from a Schengen Associated Country included on the "orange" list can enter Slovenia without restrictions or quarantine. Travellers who are a resident in a country from the red list or who arrive from such a country, shall be required to stay in quarantine for a period of 10 days. The quarantine is not imposed to travellers from the "red" list if they can provid a medical certificate proving that they have tested negative for SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19). The test should not be older than 48 hours. The test must be performed in a EU Member State or Schengen Associated Country
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On February 13, the government of Slovenia enters new exceptions about who is exempt from quarantining. As for the previous policy, travellers who are a resident in a country from the red list or who arrive from such a country, shall be required to stay in quarantine. The quarantine is not imposed to travellers from the "red" list if they can provid a medical certificate proving that they have tested negative for SARS-CoV-2. From Feb. 13 the new ordinance allows entry without quarantine and negative test also for persons who have been vaccinated against Covid-19 and persons who have recovered from Covid-19. These persons will have to produce certificates of testing or of vaccination.

description:
On March 29, 2021 the government of Slovenia forces a 10 day quarantine on all people coming from a country on the "red" list. 
It is no longer possible to end quarantine early. All people entering Slovenia must show a PCR test. As of today, a PCR test is valid only if it is performed in an EU or Schengen Area member state. All exceptions related to crossing of the border with a seven-day test have also been deleted. As of today, this exception applies only to daily work migrants, school children older than 13 years and persons who accompany them, and owners of land on both sides of the border.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
On April 12, 2021, the government of Slovenia annouces that all travelers arriving from countries on the ''Red List'' have to self-quarantine for 10 days if they do not provide a negative result from a COVID-19 PCR test taken within the previous 48 hours, a positive PCR test no more than 21 days but less than six months old, or proof of COVID-19 vaccination showing that at least seven days have passed since the second dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, at least 14 days since the second dose of the Moderna vaccine, or 21 days since the first dose of the AstraZeneca vaccine. 
International hauliers, hauliers leaving or entering the country for no more than eight hours, persons in transit, and diplomats are exempt. Nonessential travel from non-EU/Schengen Area countries remains prohibited. Individuals arriving from countries not on the Red List may enter without restriction.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_gen: People who are not vaccinated against COVID-19,Other population not specifed above
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

International hauliers, hauliers leaving or entering the country for no more than eight hours, persons in transit, and diplomats are exempt. Nonessential travel from non-EU/Schengen Area countries remains prohibited. Individuals arriving from countries not on the Red List may enter without restriction."

description:
"On April 15, 2021, the government of Slovenia annouces that all travelers arriving from countries on the ''Red List'' have to self-quarantine for 10 days if they do not provide a negative result from a COVID-19 PCR test taken within the previous 48 hours, a positive PCR test no more than 21 days but less than six months old, or proof of COVID-19 vaccination showing that at least seven days have passed since the second dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, at least 14 days since the second dose of the Moderna vaccine, or 21 days since the first dose of the AstraZeneca, the Johnson & Johnson or the Russian Sputnik V vaccine. 
International hauliers, hauliers leaving or entering the country for no more than eight hours, persons in transit, and diplomats are exempt. Nonessential travel from non-EU/Schengen Area countries remains prohibited. Individuals arriving from countries not on the Red List may enter without restriction." UPDATE: The policy ends on May 17, 2021
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_gen: People who are not vaccinated against COVID-19
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
On May 17. 2021 the government of Slovenia enforces a 10 day quarantine on all travellers coming from a Red List Country who cannot provide (1) a negative PCR test for COVID-19 that is not older than 48 hours according to the date of the swab taken, (2) a positive PCR test result that is older than 10 days but which is not older than six months, or a medical certificate of recovery from COVID-19 if not more than six months have elapsed since the beginning of symptoms, or (3) a certificate of vaccination against COVID-19, which proves that:
- at least seven days have passed since the second dose of the Comirnaty vaccine by BioNTech/Pfizer,
- at least 14 days have passed since the second dose of the COVID-19 vaccine by Moderna, Johnson & Johnson, Sputnik V, CoronaVa, or the Sinopharm vaccine,
- at least 21 days have passed since the first dose of the Vaxzevria, or the Covishield vaccine
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: As of June 7, 2021, the Government of the Republic of Slovenia announced that in the case of a person who has been in high-risk contact with the COVID-19 pathogen, the measure of home quarantine shall not be applied, if the person has recovered from COVID-19 and less than six months have elapsed since a positive PCR test or has been vaccinated against COVID-19 if less than six months have elapsed since the establishment of protection.

description:
On the 27 February 2020, the government of Slovenia on behalf of the Ministry of the Interior is monitoring the situation regarding the emergence of the coronavirus and its spread. They would enable the government to address the policy regarding Restriction and Regulation of Business in the country by effectively and appropriately handling the case of the COVID-19; regularly exchange information with representatives of the National Institute of Public Health.

And lastly, Employees who are exposed to the possibility of infection with the new coronavirus while performing their work have been asked to implement all necessary preventive and protective measures to reduce the possibility of infection.

description:
The Slovenia Government gave an update to the general public on 6 March 2020 on the latest about Coronavirus.

description:
On 13/3/2020, the government of the republic of Slovenia adopted the ordinance in relation to the   restriction & regulation of businesses in the country.
This ordinance will temporarily ban the provision and sale of goods and services directly to consumers in the territory of the Republic of Slovenia. These include accommodation, catering, wellness, sports and recreational, cinematographic, cultural, hairdressing, cosmetics and pedicure services, including gaming and other similar activities.

A grocery store is a store that mostly sells groceries."

description:
Slovenian Minister of Economic Development and Technology Zdravko Počivalšek,  and government spokesman Jelko Kacin spoke today at a press conference about the current situation regarding Covid-19.

The government adopted an amendment to the ordinance regarding the limit to the sales of goods and services, said Minister Zdravko Počivalšek.

Also, discos and nightclubs, cinemas and cultural institutions will also be prohibited from providing services. Exceptions include galleries, museums, archives and libraries, however with the restriction of 1 person per 20 m2.

Food service activities involving food and drink preparation and service is prohibited in red regions.

description:
The Government of Slovenia spokesperson, the prime minister Janez Janša in his address in the press conference on the 22/10/2020 presented an overall assessment of the situation of COVID-19 after adoption of some additional measures for the containment of the coronavirus in the last days.

The below measures will enter into force on Saturday- 22/10/2020 are : the closure of restaurants and bars, food delivery will be allowed; the closure of hotel facilities except for business delegations, diplomats and professional sports teams and the closure of shopping centers with the exception of food stores, stores with construction and technical material, pet supply stores and agricultural supply stores.

description:
The Government of Slovenia spokesperson, the prime minister Janez Janša in his address in the press conference on the 22/10/2020 presented an overall assessment of the situation of COVID-19 after adoption of some additional measures for the containment of the coronavirus in the last days.

description:
On October 21, 2020, the government of Slovenia introduced a restriction and regulation of businesses.
The number of persons in closed public spaces in which sales of goods and services are provided to consumers is restricted to 20 m2 per individual customer, or 1 customer at a time when the commercial space is less than 20 m2. description:
On March 4, 2021, the government of slovenia announced a measure on restriction and regulation of businesses for bar terraces and gardens in the two yellow regions of regions of Posavje and SE Slovenia. 
The maximum number of people on a terrace or in the garden of a restaurant is calculated according to the following distances: The distance between persons must be at least 1.5 meters, with at least 3 meters between the edges of the tables. 
This number must be clearly displayed at the entrance to the bar terrace or garden. The policy is set to last until March 12, 2021.

description: As of 12 March, 2021, the Government of the Republic of Slovenia announced the Employment Relationship Act, which determines that if an employee cannot perform his or her work due to force majeure, the risk will be shared by both the employee and the employer, thus reducing the burden of wage compensation with regard to other cases in which such compensation equals one half of the payment to which the employee would be entitled to receive for actual work performed, but not less than 70% of the minimum wage.

Slovenia is enforcing a restriction and regulation of businesses on April 1, 2021. The following activities offering and selling goods and services shall be permitted: stores that mostly sell groceries, personal care and cleaning products; stores selling medical and orthopaedic aids, gardening centres, nurseries, florists and garden and agriculture supplies in stores, agricultural stores, markets, shops offering technical goods,
newsstands and kiosks for the sale of newspapers and magazines,
individual non-medical counselling and therapeutic services.
The condition for opening is that the employees are tested once a week and general hygiene and distancing measures

description:
Authorities in Slovenia ease domestic COVID-19 – related restrictions April 23. Authorities will allow persons to travel between regions and allow gatherings of up to 10 people from different households.

As from April 26, outdoor spaces of restaurants and other catering establishments will be allowed to reopen in “orange” regions, and both outdoor and indoor spaces of such establishments will be allowed to reopen in “orange” regions, and both outdoor and indoor spaces of such establishments will be allowed to reopen in “yellow” regions.


Furthermore, accommodation facilities with up to 30 rooms will be allowed to reopen in orange regions, while all accommodation facilities can reopen in yellow regions.

description: As of June 24, 2021, the Government of the Republic of Slovenia announced that cultural events and religious ceremonies may be held in enclosed public places and outdoors if seating is provided. Where there are no fixed seats, standing places are also allowed in addition to added seats. Spectators and listeners may occupy up to 75% of the available fixed seats in enclosed public spaces and outdoors. One seat must be left vacant between participants, except for persons from the same household. In venues with no fixed seats, added seats or standing places must be placed least one metre apart, except for persons from the same household. Public cultural events may only be attended by persons meeting the recovered-vaccinated-tested requirements. This condition does not apply to persons younger than 15 years of age.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
According to the principle of proportionality and gradualism and depending on the situation in each institution, restrictions on visits are currently approved in three locations:

Koper Correctional Facility and Nova Gorica Department: visits behind the glass partition are carried out
Penitentiary institution of Maribor prison: visits are limited in such a way that only one healthy person can attend
In individual cases, the implementation and form of the visit (e.g. when it comes to a visibly ill person) is decided by the management of the institution based on the capabilities of the individual institution.

description:
Due to Coronavirus (COVID-19) the Slovenian government has announced that on March 16 public transportation (including inter-city train and bus service) will cease operations.  

Taxis for urgent transport will remain.  Cross-border bus and train services have ceased.  The Ljubljana airport is currently open, but many connecting flights from Europe to the United States have been cancelled.  The Slovenian government has advised its citizens not to travel outside of Slovenia.  

The government also announced that shops will be closed with the exception of food, pharmacies, petrol stations, banks, and post offices.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on ridership of subways and trams
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From March 30, pensioners in Slovenia will only be allowed into stores between 8am and 10am and will not be allowed into shops after 10am. UPDATE: Previously, grocery shops had to give priority during the 8-10am slot to older persons, the disabled and pregnant women. Now, this time slow will be reserved exclusively for these vulnerable groups while pensioners will not be allowed into shops after 10am at all.

The Slovenian government has declared an official end to many of its coronavirus limits, becoming the first European country to do so, after authorities confirmed less than seven new coronavirus cases each day for the past two weeks.

description: As of 25 May, 2020, pupils in their final year of primary education in Slovenia returned to their schools, which means that nearly half of the primary and secondary school population is back in the classroom, the rest continuing learning at home. Out of 87,000 children enrolled in kindergartens in the 2019/2020 school year, 56% returned to their kindergartens a week ago. However, 38,000 children are still being looked after by their parents or grandparents.

description:
As of 25 May, 2020, pupils in their final year of primary education in Slovenia returned to their schools, which means that nearly half of the primary and secondary school population is back in the classroom, the rest continuing learning at home. Out of 87,000 children enrolled in kindergartens in the 2019/2020 school year, 56% returned to their kindergartens a week ago. However, 38,000 children are still being looked after by their parents or grandparents.
 UPDATE: The Government of the Republic of Slovenia issued an update at the press conference on 25.5.2020 regarding the policy, Closure and Regulation of Schools. 

The Director of the National Education Institute, Vinko Logaj stresses that it would be useful if pupils and students were to return to school before the end of this school year, as only a traditional classroom setting can suffice to fulfil all our education objectives.

description:
All prescribed measures that have not been canceled since June 1, 2020 remain in force, including the mandatory wearing of protective masks, namely:

in closed public spaces where the mutual distance is less than 1.5 meters,
in public transport,
in persons with respiratory diseases,
in the case of employees in medical institutions according to the level of exposure,
for employees in all homes for the elderly and educational institutions for persons with special needs,
for visitors to medical institutions, homes for the elderly and educational institutions for persons with special needs.

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: "In Slovenia, for the time being, the public transport system is fully adapted in order to reduce the potential risk of spreading infections between passengers.    It is mandatory for passengers, inter alia, to wear a protective mask or other means of protecting the nose and mouth area throughout the whole duration of the transport. However, special care must be taken to not touch one’s mask while wearing it, as this could lead   to contamination of one’s hands and the risk of spreading the infection to other passengers and objects in the vehicle.  Passengers are to enter the bus through the second or back door with a valid ticket, and when entering the bus they must already be wearing a mask and must disinfect their hands, while always maintaining a distance of at least 1.5 meters between other passengers. description: Taxi services are allowed only on condition that a taxi driver ensures proper disinfection of the vehicle and the use of face masks, as well as weekly tests for the presence of SARS-CoV-2 using a PCR or rapid antigen test. Taxi drivers are allowed to provide their services only if they have a negative test result. Proof of testing is valid if it is administered in an EU Member State or Schengen Area country., or by organisations or individuals in third countries recognised as appropriate by the Institute of Microbiology and Immunology and the NLZOH and published on the NLZOH website. Mandatory weekly testing is also introduced for public passenger transport drivers and accompanying rail staff.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on  private vehicles in public circulation
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Taxi services are allowed only on condition that a taxi driver ensures proper disinfection of the vehicle and the use of face masks, as well as weekly tests for the presence of SARS-CoV-2 using a PCR or rapid antigen test. Taxi drivers are allowed to provide their services only if they have a negative test result. Proof of testing is valid if it is administered in an EU Member State or Schengen Area country., or by organisations or individuals in third countries recognised as appropriate by the Institute of Microbiology and Immunology and the NLZOH and published on the NLZOH website. Mandatory weekly testing is also introduced for public passenger transport drivers and accompanying rail staff.

description:
On April 1, 2021, Slovenia enforces a restriction and regulation of businesses specifically for shopping centers. Shopping centres shall have to: provide 30 m² per customer throughout the shopping centre,
have a separate entrance and exit for customers. On top of that shopping centers should ensure minimum possible contact with consumers, regular ventilating the premises; and the provision of hand disinfection dispensers for consumers at entry and exit points; all the hygiene recommendations

description:
SARS-CoV-2 infection and reinstates the obligation to wear a face mask in open public places or outside, except during individual sporting activities on green areas under certain conditions.


The use of a face mask is mandatory for the driver and passengers in: 

public scheduled services, special regular services, regular non-scheduled services and occasional passenger services, with the number of passengers limited to the number of registered seats less the seats to the right of the driver and the row of seats directly behind the driver for public scheduled intercity services, special scheduled and occasional passenger services operated by category M2 and M3 vehicles, and
special scheduled services, regular non-scheduled passenger services and occasional passenger services operated by category M1 vehicles with a maximum of eight seats for passengers, up to a maximum of six seats occupied.

description: Mask or other forms of protection covering mouth and nose are mandatory: in all closed public spaces, on public transport, in open public spaces or outside and in personal vehicles.  Masks or other forms of protection covering mouth and nose are not compulsory for: children younger than six years of age; pupils in primary schools and students in secondary schools but only when they are in their classrooms; preschool teachers and their assistants when they interact with children, primary school teachers up to and including the fifth grade when they interact with children or pupils; teachers at higher vocational colleges and universities if they lecture behind a protective barrier made of glass or similar material; persons practising individual sports if a distance of at least three metres is maintained; persons or members of the same household when taking a walk on green spaces or practising sports or recreational activities if a distance of at least three metres is maintained at all times; in personal vehicles when more than one person or member of the same household is in the vehicle.

description: Masks are mandatory: in all closed public spaces, on public transport, in open public spaces or outside, if a distance of at least 1,5 metres is not maintained and in personal vehicles.    From 12 April 2021, protective masks must be worn in all enclosed public spaces, on public transport, in open places and outside where a distance of 1.5 metres cannot be maintained and in private vehicles when travelling with members of other households for work purposes. Masks are not compulsory for children under the age of six, primary school pupils up to 5th grade when in classrooms, and people practicing non-contact sports, if a distance of 3 metres can be maintained.

description:
Transportation Options:

Quick facts:

Are commercial flights operating? Yes

Is public transportation operating? Yes

Airport: Ljubljana Airport is open, but with a reduced number of flights.
Cross border train/bus service: Operating.  It is passengers’ responsibility to ensure they meet entry requirements for cross-border service.  Passengers must wear a face mask and keep a safety distance of at least 1 meter.
Internal train/bus service: Operating.  Passengers must disinfect their hands upon entry, wear a face mask and keep a safety distance of at least 1 meter.  The Infrastructure Ministry has established a hotline at 01 478 85 12 to address questions on public transportation.
Taxis: Available. Facemasks required.
Fines for Non-Compliance:

Inspectors are enforcing quarantine orders through random visits to residences of those quarantined.  Travel restrictions are also enforced.  Violators face hefty fines.

description: The Ordinance amending the Ordinance on temporary measures to reduce the risk of infection and spread of COVID-19 does not abolish the obligation to wear face masks in open public spaces if the minimum distance of 1.5 metres between persons cannot be maintained. Exceptions for which the use of a face mask is not mandatory now include speakers at events or gatherings in enclosed public spaces, provided that they meet the vaccinated-tested-recovered requirements and maintain a distance of at least two metres from other participants.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Is public transportation operating? Yes

Airport: Ljubljana Airport is open, but with a reduced number of flights.
Cross border train/bus service: Operating.  It is passengers’ responsibility to ensure they meet entry requirements for cross-border service.  Passengers must wear a face mask and keep a safety distance of at least 1 meter.
Internal train/bus service: Operating.  Passengers must disinfect their hands upon entry, wear a face mask and keep a safety distance of at least 1 meter.  The Infrastructure Ministry has established a hotline at 01 478 85 12 to address questions on public transportation.
Taxis: Available. Facemasks required.

description: Masks are mandatory in all closed public spaces, on public transport, in open public spaces or outside, if a distance of at least 1,5 metres is not maintained and in personal vehicles. Masks are not compulsory for children younger than six years of age; primary school pupils up to and including the 5th grade, but only when they are in their classrooms; preschool teachers and their assistants when they interact with children;  teachers at higher vocational colleges and universities if they lecture behind a protective barrier made of glass or similar material; speakers in enclosed public places or premises if an interpersonal distance of at least 2 metres is provided and if they meet the RVT* condition; persons practising individual sports if a distance of at least three metres is maintained;  persons or members of the same household when taking a walk on green spaces or practising sports or recreational activities if a distance of at least 1,5 metres is maintained at all times;  in personal vehicles when more than one person or member of the same household is in the vehicle; direct communication with deaf and hard-of-hearing people (if it is possible to maintain a distance of two metres) and Slovenian sign language interpreters.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
